Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Industrial Enzymes from the Microbiomes of Household Insects
Award.AbstractNarration:
Developing enzymes that can catalyze efficient conversion of plant cell wall material (lignocellulose) to fermentable sugars or high-value chemical building blocks is an important goal of many industrial enzyme companies. However, the current enzymes being used for plant cell wall degradation are active under a limited set of conditions; they can't, for example, deal with very acidic or basic conditions. This research project seeks to identify industrial enzymes that can be used to break down hard-to-degrade materials such as plant cell walls. Such enzymes are useful in producing energy and in remediating pollution. This project seeks to find new enzymes that are active in diverse conditions and, as such, maximally useful. The use of these improved enzymes would allow industrial processes to be cheaper, higher volume and more efficient.

This research will result in a proof-of-concept, specifically the production of at least one commercially relevant enzyme from the microbiome of household insects. The project will also result in providing the basis for at least two types of patents: 1) process of isolating lignocellulosic enzymes from camel crickets and dermestid beetles and 2) the application of recombinant enzymes identified in the course this project. The I-Corps program will enable the team to seek out industrial partnerships to customize the proposed research to the needs and interests of the industrial partners. In performing the research goals outlined in this proposal, the team will foremost have the opportunity to mature the development of an isolation and screening platform designed to identify microorganisms and enzymes from household insect microbiomes that have utility for biotechnological/industrial applications and to form relationships with target technology companies. In addition the proposed research could also answer several questions about the ecology of the household insects, their microbiota, and the enzymes used by these insects to degrade and digest permanent household materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While initially focusing on the discovery of new ants and their shifting distribution, Rob Dunn and colleagues discovered an entire zoo of creatures could be found in homes (Martin et al. 2015). This realization led to many discoveries, including that of a giant, camel cricket that had, largely unnoticed, spread basement to basement across North America (Barberan et al. 2015 Grantham et al. 2015; Epps et al. 2014) (Figure 1). This prompted a new question. Could any of these indoor species actually be "useful”? One of the things that unites many of the species that live indoors is a dependence on the building materials, materials that have been chosen so as to be "permanent," or as close to permanent as possible (Martin et al. 2015). Dunn predicted that the insects that live indoors, particularly off of building materials, as appears to be the case with both camel crickets and dermestid beetles, should likely possess the ability to digest intractable compounds. Some of these same hard to digest compounds are industry targets including plant based materials rich in lignin and cellulose.

Several industries already use enzymes to achieve lignocellulose degradation such as those that produce biofuels, animal feed, detergents, and food and beverages. We interviewed several target customers from three types of companies: 1) those which produce and distribute enzymes 2) those companies which produce lignocellulosic biofuels and 3) those industries which produce underutilized lignocellulosic materials. In interviewing these customers our team developed a business model and continued to refine the model based on customer feedback during a total of 119 interviews. As the result of this project, we understand the most enzymes which would be valuable to customers and also have a detailed understanding of how these enzymes would solve problems in their existing company structure. With this information, we have begun to identify, recombinantly express, and purify enzymes that would meet potential customer needs. 

The experience and data collected as a result of the NSF I-Corps Program has reshaped our way of thinking about applied research. The customer validation was crucial to determining if these enzymes would be of industrial relevance. Ultimately these interviews revealed that components of this technology is very valuable and requires more lab data before commercialization. 

 


Last Modified: 06/01/2016
Modified by: Robert Dunn
